page.title: 16Home Life-How we wash.
page.content: An investigation was undertaken by a group of 12 and 13 year olds into how they and their parents wash themselves. Every perdon claimed to wash parts of their body at least once every day.Hands and face were most frequently washed, possibly because they are the most 'public' parts of the body. Most children wash their faces with a 'flannel', rubbing soap onto it to create a lather and then rubbling this onto their faces. Many adults create a lather with their hands and using them in place of a flannel. Teeth are cleaned twice a day using a brush and paste. Many stated that they had a 'favourite' toothbrush which they had had for months and which had bristles which were bent over. Dentists inform us that these brushes
